name: Fort Pulaski National Monument
description: For much of the 19th century, masonry fortifications were the United States’ main defense against overseas enemies. However, during the Civil War, new technology proved its superiority over these forts. Using rifled cannons, the U.S. Army compelled the Confederate garrison inside Fort Pulaski to surrender. The siege was a landmark experiment in the history of military science and invention.
shortDescription: For much of the 19th century, masonry fortifications were the United States’ main defense against overseas enemies. However, during the Civil War, new technology proved its superiority over these fort...

operatingHours.description: Fort Pulaski National Monument is open year round from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 pm, except for New Years, Thanksgiving, and Christmas Days. Last entry into the park is at 4:30 pm. Historic Fort Pulaski is open 9:00 a.m. to 4:30 pm and the Visitor Center is open from 9:00 am to 5:00 pm.

fees.title: Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: A per person fee of $10 is required to visit Fort Pulaski and the surrounding areas. Admission is valid for 7 consecutive days. Youth 15 and under are admitted free of charge. Only available at the entrance station to Fort Pulaski National Monument. Credit/Debit Only

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: Commercial bus/van tours are charged the per person fee for the number of persons on board.

climate.weatherDescription: Savannah has a humid sub tropical climate with over two hundred days of sunshine each year. Summers are typically hot, bright and humid with afternoon thunderstorms common. Temperatures often range from the lower 70s to the mid 90s F. Spring and autumn can be quite pleasant with temperatures ranging from the upper 50s into the 80s F. The winter months are usually dry. Temperatures can be cooler than one would expect, ranging from the upper 30s through the 60s F generally, though sudden cold snaps can occur.

images.title: The Battered Walls of Fort Pulaski
images.altText: The red masonry walls of Fort Pulaski still show battle damage over 150 years later.
images.caption: A walk along the outside of Fort Pulaski reveals damaged walls over 150 years after the Civil War.

images.title: The Casemates of a Fort
images.altText: The brick of the fort glow in the late afternoon light. The arches inside the fort reveal a cannon i
images.caption: Fort Pulaski shows off its classic arched architecture and cannon.

images.title: The Cockspur Island Lighthouse
images.altText: The white masonry Cockspur Island lighthouse sits in the Savannah River.
images.caption: The Cockspur Island Lighthouse still stands guard over the south channel of the Savannah River and Fort Pulaski.

images.title: The Sentinel
images.altText: A great blue heron stands watch on top of the fort's brick walls.
images.caption: A great blue heron stands on the top of Fort Pulaski like a lonely sentinel.

images.title: The Ladies of a Fort
images.altText: Two women dressed in mid nineteenth century civilian attire watch through looking glasses
images.caption: Volunteer living historians play an important role for the National Park Service and Fort Pulaski National Monument.

images.title: Night Cannon Firing at Fort Pulaski
images.altText: The night sky is illuminated as a cannon fires at Fort Pulaski
images.caption: Artillery demonstrations are an important part of the interpretation program at Fort Pulaski.
